characters: THE AMAZING MISTER FELL AND HIS REMARKABLE FEATS OF

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Title Card: The Beginning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost a montage: A huge black SNAKE slips along a tree branch. The Snake’s head whispers into EVE’s ear. A hand, Eve’s, picks an apple from a tree. She takes a bi Grins. Passes it to ADAM. (They are both tastefully naked would not make them white people.) Adam also takes a bite And then he grins lecherously at Eve. Tasteful blackout.. Time lapse... A rumble of supernatural THUNDER! An angel in white robes (AZIRAPHALE but we can’t see his face), holding a flaming sword, gestures impressively tow an exit gate: they have to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Garden is walled. Inside, a perfect place of greenery Outside, something more like a desert or an African plain Adam and Eve, now wearing leaf-based clothes, in tears, a running, desperately away from the Garden. Adam is holdin something we cannot see. Eve is pregnant. Animals roar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching Adam and Eve leave, are the angel, AZIRAPHALE, a beside him, on a tree, a very, very large black SNAKE. Th Snake HISSES loudly.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Sorry. What was that? The snake TRANSMUTES into a male Demon. He’s dressed in robes, as opposed to the Angel’s white robes, and his eye look like the eyes of a snake. (IF WE DO WINGS his are gr feathers, the angel’s are white.)

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I said, Well, that one went down like a lead balloon.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes, it did, rather.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Bit of an overreaction, if you ask me. First offense and everything. And I can’t see what’s so bad about knowing the difference between good and evil, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: It must BE bad. Otherwise you wouldn't have tempted them into it.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: They just said, Get up there and make some trouble. So I did.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Obviously. You’re a demon. It’s what you do.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Not very subtle of Him, though. Fruit tree in the middle of a garden, with a don’t touch sign. If He really didn’t want them to eat the apples, He could have put it on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Best not to speculate. It’s all part of the ineffable plan. I don’t like the look of that weather. Low rumble of non-supernatural thunder on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Didn't you have a flaming sword?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Er...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did. It was flaming like anything. What happened to it?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Er...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Lost it, have you?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: (mutters inaudibly) I gave it away.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I gave it away. They looked so miserable. And there are vicious animals, and it’s going to be cold out there, and she’s expecting already, and I said, here you go, flaming sword, don’t thank me, and don’t let the sun go down on you here.... I do hope I didn’t do the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You’re an angel. How can you do the wrong thing?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: It’s been bothering me. In the distance, Adam uses the flaming sword on some poor lion. Aziraphale winces. NB it’s pronounced Azeerafail.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: ...I’ve been worrying too. What if I did the right thing, with the whole eat-the-apple business. A demon can get into a lot of trouble for doing the right thing. Funny if we both got it wrong, eh?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Not really. Not funny at all. The Thunderstorm begins in earnest.  TITLE CARD: ELEVEN YEARS AGO. Buddy Holly’s song “Every Day” plays, beginning with a ti tick tick and... Every day, it's a-getting closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of Aziraphale’s Bookshop. It’s a run-do Secondhand/antiquarian Bookshop of the kind you used to s lots of in London... INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOKSHOP - AFTERNOON AZIRAPHALE is answering the phone. He has not changed sin we saw him as an angel. He looks like a happy, affluent, book dealer. He’s a kind-looking gentleman whose sartoria style runs to bow-ties. He thinks a little tartan is nift and would use the world nifty with pride. His bookshop is chaotic, crowded, glorious, dusty. He is sitting at a tab at a desk piled high with books.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: First edition of Gibbons’ Decline and Fall? Yes, I definitely have a set here somewhere. Six volumes, let me see, 1776... No, I don’t know where it is, but you’re welcome to come in and have a root around. And if I come across it, I could telephone you. He writes down a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy to help. He puts down the phone. Makes an “I’m a bit naughty but a profoundly lovable” face (a la Boris Johnson). Sits back his chair, returns to reading his copy of Gibbons’s Decli and Fall of the Roman Empire volume I, and drops the phon number in the bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s 7:30pm in Midsummer, the streetlights are going on, people are leaving their offices. One person is going to work: CROWLEY is wearing stylish very black sunglasses, a very nice suit. He is carrying a clipboard and a Thermos flask. His hairstyle is perfect for somewhere around a decade a He glances around a little theatrically. He puts on a day orange donkey jacket. He hangs an Identity Card on a lanyard around his neck. T he walks in to the BT Tower building lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A security desk. Behind it, a bored female SECURITY GUARD does a crossword.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Rataway Pest Control.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: I thought your lot weren’t due in until tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Preliminary inspection. Traps go down tomorrow. My job’s to tell them where.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Bloody everywhere. I’ve never seen anything like it. I put down a tuna sandwich yesterday, never saw it again. Health and safety closed off the upper floors as a health hazard until you lot get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley and another Security Guard are in the lift.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: Sunglasses?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It’s my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I’m not going to be able to let you wander around on your own up here. Unescorted. Lot of communications go through here. All the mobile phone services, for a start.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lift dings, and Crowley and the Guard step out. The f is empty. Night lighting. But we hear a SCRATCHING. Crowley looks around. Every surface is alive. A nose. Sharp teeth. A twitch of tail. RATS. Hundreds of them! Tiny sinister red eyes glow at us from all over. A beat, then they move -- they are coming towards us! The Guard steps back into the lift.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: You know. I’m just going to wait here.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t blame you. The lift door closes. Crowley walks forward. He takes out thermos, unscrews the top, pours himself a cup of steamin tea. And Crowley... smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beautiful job! Thank you all, so much men! A lady rat chirps angrily.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, yes, obviously, ladies too. Nice job! You can all go home. And, yeah, stay cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into a room filled with computer and BT equipmen All of it old-fashioned and out-dated equipment: the computers of yesteryear, and some cables. Lots of green and red lights flashing. Crowley pours his tea onto the unit. Then he pours the re of the tea from the thermos. All around the room CONSOLE Lights start to flicker. Something electronic buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley enters the lift.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Left something back in the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONSOLE Lights flickering. And then they start to GO OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley walks out of the lobby. On the pavement is a BUSINESSMAN on an old-fashioned pre-smartphone phone.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: No, I understand. That’s why we have to close this now. So. Seventy grand. Our final offer. What do you say? And then he shakes the phone. Tries redialling, and we fo Crowley, who is taking off his jacket, past people on the pavement, a WOMAN,

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: No Arthur, you can pick me up here. I’m on the corner of... can you hear me? Hello? ...a TEENAGE BOY...

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE BOY
dialogues.text: Look, I know I kissed her at the party. But I mean, that doesn’t mean I wanted to dump you. I’m really sorry. I’m really hullo? Hullo? Over this we can hear a telecom voice saying “We are sorr All circuits are busy.” And Crowley is smiling. What a wonderful day. Checks his beautiful black watch, and stresses a little. He’s late. He reaches his car, a beautiful vintage Bentley Sports C and pulls out onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles with the radio, and to the beat of either KILL QUEEN by QUEEN, or a seriously rocking cover of Buddy Hol “EVERY DAY”, he starts driving through the London streets ridiculous speeds. And as he drives, we see a Title Card with GOOD OMENS on and hear our NARRATOR:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good Omens. Being a Narrative of Certain Events occurring in the last eleven years of human history, in strict accordance, as shall be shown, with The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small country churchyard. Possibly ruined. Rather creep We move through it slowly... It’s misty, and brrr.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a dark and stormy night. It should have been, but that’s the weather for you. But don’t let the fog, with rain later, fool you. Just because it’s a mild night doesn’t mean the forces of evil weren’t abroad. They’re everywhere. That’s the whole point. And by now we’ve reached two very evil-looking gentlemen, standing in the shadows. One squat and monstrous, LIGUR. tall, thin and monstrous, HASTUR. They have something -- box-shaped object -- behind them, in the dark shadows. Hastur has been hand-rolling a tobacco cigarette. He puts in his mouth, lights it with a flame from his fingertip. the flame’s light, we get a good look at them. They don’t have horns, they wear vintage suits and shabby raincoats, but they aren’t human. Weird eyes.  Skin like frogs, or pitted with terrible acne. They are trying hard to pass for human, but not even the fog is helping.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Take these two. They’ve been lurking in the fog for an hour. But they've been pacing themselves, and could lurk until dawn.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Gissa drag. Hastur hands him the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Bugger this for a lark. He should have been here an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His name is Hastur. He is a Duke of Hell.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: You trust him?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ligur. Also a Duke of Hell.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Be a funny old world if Demons went around trusting each other. What’s he calling himself these days?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Crowley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Titles and Rocking Music. Crowley, still speeding looks in his rear-view mirror. A POLICE CAR, behind him, turns on its blue light.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: No. And now the SIREN starts.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do not have time for this.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two POLICE OFFICERS are thrilled to be doing a high-speed chase in the fog. No, really they are.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE 1
dialogues.text: The nutter’s doing a hundred and ten. In the fog. You know what this means?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE 2
dialogues.text: We get to do a hundred and fifteen. Brilliant. What the hell kind of car is that?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE 1
dialogues.text: Vintage Bentley, I think. Come on, nutter. Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise of the siren is starting to get to him. Crowley irritated, snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE 2
dialogues.text: (into police radio) In pursuit of a speeding vehicle. Vintage Bentley. And we're... The Police Car engine makes a whining sound, and then it slows down and stops.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE 2, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're having mechanical problems. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car, on the side of the road. Fog. The car’s steaming. They open the bonnet. We move from police officer to police officer: they look horrified and confused. And now we look at the engine. Where the engine ought to be is just GREEN GOO, steaming bubbling gently.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ligur and Hastur, still lurking. Hastur crushes the dog-e under his foot. We can see a little more of the object be him. A car's headlights approach in the fog.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Here he comes now, the flash bastard.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: What's that he's drivin'?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: It's a car. A horseless carriage. Didn't they have them last time you was up here?

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: They had a man walking in front with a red flag.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: They've come on a bit since then. A car door SLAMs.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: What’s he like?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Crowley? Been up here too long. And he wears sunglasses, even when he dunt need to. We look from Hastur’s TOAD-LIKE eyes to Ligur’s FLY-EYES, we suspect why Crowley might want to wear Sunglasses. Crowley is Sauntering up the path. He stops. They stare a him.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All hail Satan.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: All hail Satan.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Er. Hi guys. Sorry I'm late, but, well, you know how it is on the A40 at Denham, and then I tried to cut up towards Chorleywood --  12. Hastur interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Now we art all here, we must recount the Deeds of the Day.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: ("we do? Oh, I remember this.”) Of course. Deeds. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: I have tempted a priest. As he walked down the street and saw the pretty girls in the sun, I put Doubt into his mind. He would have been a saint, but within a decade we shall have him. Ligur makes approving guttural throaty noises, as if this the best thing he’s ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: (politely) Nice one.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: I have corrupted a politician. I let him think a tiny bribe would not hurt. Within a year we shall have him. Hatsur hisses approval. They stare at Crowley. Him next. that’s good, because he has the BEST one...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You'll like this. We look at their faces and know that they won’t.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I brought down every London area mobile phone network tonight. There is a baffled silence.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Yes?  13.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t easy. I had to send rats into the BT Tower, and I had to pour tea into the network controller, while the backup system was offline for maintainance...

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: And what exactly has that done to secure souls for our master?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Oh come on! Fifteen million pissed- off people? Who take it out on each other? Who take it out on everyone else? Ruined days. Ruined nights. The knock-on effects are incalculable...

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: It’s not... craftsmanship.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Head office don’t seem to mind. They love me down there. Guys, times are changing. So, what’s up? Hastur reaches down and picks up the object at his feet. kind of wicker basket. He hands it to Ligur, who grins unpleasantly...

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: This is.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: And it’s up to me to...?

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Yes.  14.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You know. This sort of... well, it really isn’t my scene.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Your scene. Your starring role. Take it.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Like you said. Times are changing.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: They're coming to an end, for a start.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: They love you down there. And what an opportunity. Ligur here would give his right arm to be you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Somebody's right arm, anyway. Hastur has produced a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Sign here. Crowley writes A. J. Crowley on the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: No. Your real name. Crowley uses the tip of his finger, and writes a sigil wh burns where he’s touched it. The entire sheet of paper go up like flash paper. Ligur holds out the large wicker basket. It could be a do basket, but it’s the wrong shape... Crowley looks dejecte

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: You will receive instructions. Why so glum? The moment we have been working for all these centuries is at hand!  15.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Centuries.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Our moment of eternal triumph awaits! Crowley is forcing a smile. It does not convince anyone.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Triumph.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: And you will be a tool of that glorious destiny!

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Glorious. Tool. Yeah. He takes the basket from Ligur

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll, er, be off then. Shall I? Get it over with. Not that I want to get it over with. Obviously. But you know me. Keen. Two implacable Demon faces. Crowley backs away down the path.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I'll be popping along. See you guys ar- see you. Er. Great. Fine. Ciao. In the mist. We hear the Bentley car door slam.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Wossat mean. Ciao?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: It's Italian. It means “food”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aziraphale walks in. The Waitress points to his favourite table, kept free for him. The Sushi Chef behind the counter says,  16.

dialogues.speaker: SUSHI CHEF
dialogues.text: (in japanese) Here is a selection of your favourite rolls, Honoured Aziraphale-San. The waitress, who puts them, along with a cup of steaming tea, on the table, and bows. Aziraphale bows back.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: (In fluent Japanese) You honour me. Thank you Suzuki- San. He sits at his table. Smiles as he eats his first nibble. Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley is driving. He looks miserable, stressed and upse The mystery basket is on the back seat. He turns on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Oh. Shit....

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the FT index finished up 5 points today, after vigorous trading.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: ..-Ohshitohshitohshit. Why me?

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because you earned it, Crowley. Didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Leave it to me, Lord.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That is what we are doing, Crowley. But if anything goes wrong, then those involved will suffer greatly. Even you, Crowley. Especially you. Crowley nods. He’s terrified.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here are your instructions.  17. And Crowley FREEZES for a moment, as information is downloaded directly into his brain. (Perhaps, from behind dark glasses, his eyes could glow for a moment.) A bad idea to do this while he’s driving, because a LORRY heading towards him in the fog. At the last moment, he gets his brain back, and TWISTS TH STEERING WHEEL HARD, slamming out of the Lorry’s way, a maneuver that throws the wicker basket across the back se And now, for the first time, we can see what it is: a wic bassinet. And the sleeping NEWBORN BABY inside it opens i eyes, and it WAILS... TITLE CARD: Bringing about Armageddon can be dangerous. TITLE CARD: Please do not attempt this in your own home. Now we get the rest of the TITLE CREDITS. And these occur, being dealt out while we in THE NARRATOR’S WORLD. A darkened space, like a studio or a warehouse belonging rich madman who can afford anything he wants. We can see a big, beautiful, globe of the world, and a newspaper on a table. Other things that are on the table right now include a pack of cards and a little wind-up dinosaur skeleton. A hand comes out of the darkness, and starts to rotate th globe. Our narrator is authoritative and reassuring: the voice of history, of science, of wisdom. As he speaks things ANIMATE: We see, first, the BIG BANG, SCIENTISTS. The CERN particle accelerator.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Current theories on the creation of the Universe state that it came into being about twenty billion years ago. By the same token the earth itself is generally supposed to be about four and a half billion years old. (beat) These dates are incorrect. Now we see ancient scholars, working with abacuses, scrol and scraps of parchment...  18. NARRATOR (CONT’D) Medieval Jewish scholars put the date of the Creation at 3760 BC. Greek Orthodox theologians put Creation as far back as 5508 BC. (beat) Also incorrect. Now, Ussher and his assistants, with a huge genealogical of the line of Adam, and how long everyone lived... NARRATOR (CONT’D) Archbishop James Ussher claimed that the Heaven and the Earth were created in 4004 BC. One of his aides took the calculation further, and was able to announce that the Earth was created on Sunday the 21st of October, 4004 BC, at 9.00 a.m. This too was incorrect. By almost a quarter of an hour. We're back in the Narrator’s space. His face is in the shadows, but he’s talking to us directly. NARRATOR (CONT’D) This proves two things: Firstly, that God moves in extremely mysterious ways. God does not play dice with the universe; He plays an ineffable game of His own devising, which might be compared to playing poker in a pitch-dark room, for infinite stakes, with a Dealer who won't tell you the rules. (beat) Secondly, the Earth's a Libra. The Narrator leans into the light and picks up the newspa Reads to us: NARRATOR (CONT’D) The astrological prediction for Libra in the 'Your Stars Today' column of the Tadfield Advertiser. LIBRA. You may be feeling run down and always in the same old daily round. A friend is important to you. You may be vulnerable to a stomach upset today, so avoid salads. Help could come from an unexpected quarter.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A green Morris Traveller is driving cautiously along the outside the hospital. Inside the Car are Deirdre Young an her husband, Arthur Young. He is in his forties, she is i her late thirties and hugely pregnant. This is her first child. But everything’s very normal...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This was perfectly correct on every count except for the bit about the salads.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Are we there yet? Arthur? Seven minutes apart.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: It's definitely this way. It’s just the roads look all different int he dark...

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: The nuns said to come in when they were seven to ten minutes apart.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: It’s a bit, um. Well. Nuns.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Do we have any egg and cress sandwiches? Mrs Young reaches for a sandwich, and as she does so, has contraction... A Sirening MOTORCADE zooms past them -- an ambulance, followed by three black cars.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Arthur. Just follow them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Rapid-cutting, ultra-adrenaline: The Ambulance i going at speed. In it is HARRIET DOWLING, the movie-star- beautiful wife of the American Cultural Attache to London Very pregnant. Standing near her, and being thrown around TWO SECRET SERVICE AGENTS. Holding a video screen, and a video camera. It’s a pre-skype Video hookup from the old days.  20. On the video screen we can see TAD (THADDEUS J) DOWLING, cultural attache, back in the US, soon to be presidential hopeful, in a White House meeting. He’s talking to her:

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: Breathe, honey. Just breathe.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I am breathing, goddammit, Tad. Why aren’t you here?

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: Honey. I’m with you. I’m just also here with the President.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH
dialogues.text: Hey Harriet. Sorry we had to borrow your husband.

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: Hon, I’d better get back to the strategy conference.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You are meant to be with me, you useless sonofabitch (Contraction).

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: Honey, you're going to the best place we could find at short notice. The, uh...

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE
dialogues.text: St Beryl’s Convent Birthing Hospital, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: St Beryl’s. Right. Honey, you just keep on having the baby. I’1l be right here with you. Birth is the single most joyous co-experience that two human beings can share, and I’m not going to miss a second of it.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH
dialogues.text: Tad. If we can return to the matter in hand?

dialogues.speaker: TAD DOWLING
dialogues.text: I’1ll get back to you honey. And the screen goes blank. Mrs Dowling bites back some re impressive swearing.  21. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT An old convent, part of which has been converted into a s birthing hospital. We are looking at a dozen NUNS. The Mo Superior is facing them. The SATANIC nature of the place given away by the upside-down Cross on the wall beside th Mother Superior.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: The child of the American Cultural Attache. Everything is ready. Tonight, it begins.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Excuse me Mother Superior but I was wondering where the other baby was going to come from, not the American baby, I mean that’s obvious, that’s just the birds and the bees, but the, you know --

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Mr Crowley is on his way with our dark master to be, Sister Mary Loquacious. Now. We are Nuns of the Chattering Order of Saint Beryl. And tonight is what our order was created for. We can hear the ambulance Siren drawing up outside. MOTHER SUPERIOR (CONT’D) Places! And the Nuns begin to move, and as they do, they begin to chat to each other, each one saying whatever’s on her min Mother Superior reaches out and tips the upside down cros right-way up. And she SMILES. EXT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT Behind the Ambulance and the Motorcade of Black Cars, we a Green Morris Traveller.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Right.  22. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT RECEPTION - NIGHT We watch as two things are happening at the same time. Harriet Dowling is wheeled in, followed by a secret servi man with a video camera, OTHER SECRET SERVICE MEN saying things like “Clear!” into their earpieces, and all is commotion... Meanwhile Mr and Mrs Young walk up to the front desk. He’ carrying a little suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Deirdre Young. I phoned. Contractions now five minutes apart.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER TERESA GARRULOUS
dialogues.text: Welcome to St Beryl’s. We’re all ready for you. Room Three. Deirdre turns to Mr Young, takes the Suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Obviously Arthur will be with me, while I’m in labour...

dialogues.speaker: SISTER TERESA GARRULOUS
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. We believe fathers just... complicate the process for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: But-- Mr Young looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Not going to argue with Nuns. Nurses. Know what they’re doing, Deirdre. I'll be. Um. He produces his pipe, from his pocket. Deirdre glares at him as she is swept off in a storm of nuns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT Mr Young walks out into the driveway to smoke his pipe. H tamps down some tobacco -- clearly a man for whom the rit of smoking are more important than actually smoking itsel He starts looking for his lighter...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It may help to understand human affairs if you notice that most of the great triumphs and tragedies of history are caused, not by people being fundamentally good or fundamentally bad, but by people being fundamentally people. And a Vintage Bentley pulls up. Crowley gets out, grabs t carry-cot, and heads towards us.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Has it started yet?

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: They made me go out.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Any idea how long we've got?

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: I think we were, er, getting on with it, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Got it. What room is she in?

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: We're in Room Three. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT CORRIDOR - NIGHT We're in the Corridor. Looking at Sister Mary, from the P of the baby in the carrycot.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Only I'd expected funny eyes. Or teensy-weensy little hoofikins. Or a widdle tail.  24. She's taken the baby out of the carrier and is turning it over...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It's definitely him.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Fancy me holding the Antichrist. And counting his little toesy- wosies... Do you look like your daddy? I bet you do. I bet you look like your daddywaddykins....

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t. Take him up to Room three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching Sister Mary outside the room, with a three on it from further down the corridor the Secret Service Men gla at her suspiciously. Mary goes in, with the antichrist ba to the room in which Deirdre Young is asleep. Mrs Young has BABY B in a bassinet sleeping soundly besid her. Sister Mary carefully takes the ID tag off the Young’s ba and just as carefully attaches it to the Antichrist Baby. Sister Mary looks at the two babies. They look quite simi don’t they? She puts on the kettle. A HESITANT KNOCK on the door. Mr Young.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Has it happened yet? I’m the father. The husband. Both.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ooh yes. Congratulations. Your lady wife’s asleep, poor pet. Mr Young looks down at the babies. Baby B and the Antichr baby.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Twins? Nobody said anything about twins.  25.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, no! This one's yours. The other one's... someone else's. Just looking after him. No, this one's definitely yours, your ambassadorship. From the top of his head to the tips of his hoofywoofies - which he hasn't got.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: All, er, present and correct, is he?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Normal. Very, very normal. You don't have much of an accent. Have you been over here long?

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: About ten years. The job moved, you see, and I had to move with it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It must have been very different where you were before. She's making tea.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Er...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Taller buildings, for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: There’s the Alliance and Leicester offices. (he’s given tea) Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And I expect you go to a lot of HER garden parties.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Well, fetes mainly. Deidre makes jam for them, you know. And I sometimes have to help with the White Elephant.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I expect they're tribute. I read where these foreign potentates give her majesty all sorts of things. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want tea? There’s actual coffee in one of the vendible machines on the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Tea’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My word. You have gone native, haven't you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything in this delivery room is fast-cut, with adventurous camera moves and POUNDING MUSIC: we see the s on foreheads, sharp lighting. It is a much bigger deliver room, which is good because it has to fit a lot of people have our SECRET SERVICE MEN, one of them with his video camera, one of them holding up a small screen, a couple o MINOR US OFFICIALS, nurse nuns, and Harriet Dowling, in t process of giving birth to Baby A, loudly and angrily.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE
dialogues.text: The Eagle is Landing. Repeat. The Eagle is Landing. Two nuns give each other significant looks. One of them, Sister Teresa Garrulous, nods and leaves. More POUNDING MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An intimate classical concert, somewhere nice, like an ar museum. A String Quintet (two cellos) is playing Schubert’s Strin Quintet. The melody washes over a beaming and well-fed Aziraphale, sitting happily in the well-dressed audience, at perfect peace with the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pounding music. Sister Teresa Garrulous isn’t actually running down the corridors, but she is moving as fast as can, scanning every open room as she passes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Mary is presenting Mr Young with a selection of pi iced biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Now these are what we call “bis- cuits”, but you’ll be looking at them and going (fingerquotes) “cookies”!

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, I definitely call them biscuits. BLAM! The door opens, Mrs Young stirs in her bed, and Sis Teresa enters, to see: Sleeping Baby B... Mr Young... Sleeping the Antichrist Baby... Sister Mary... Sleeping Mrs Young... Her puzzled glance returns to the babies... Sister Teresa looks furious, but only for a second. She looks at Sister Mary and WINKS. Sister Mary points at Baby B and WINKS. Sister Teresa looks happy, wheels the bassinet with baby it out of the door, and TAKES OFF DOWN THE CORRIDOR WITH IT... Sister Mary smiles happily. FREEZE FRAME. The Narrator walks in front of the frozen frame, holding long pointer.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: As methods of human communication go, the wink is quite versatile. For example, Sister Teresa’s wink meant,  28. Sister Teresa comes through the door, furious:

dialogues.speaker: SISTER TERESA GARRULOUS
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been? We're ready to make the switch, and here's you in the wrong room with the Adversary, Destroyer of Kings, Angel of the Bottomless Pit, Great Beast that is called Dragon, Prince of This World, Father of Lies, Spawn of Satan, and Lord of Darkness, drinking tea. Do you realize I've nearly been shot?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And, as far as she was concerned, Sister Mary's answering wink meant: Sister Mary looks up from her tea, and says, sharp, sexy out of character (the voice could be done by Sister Teres

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: This child is the Adversary, Destroyer of Kings, Angel of the Bottomless Pit, Great Beast that is called Dragon, Prince of This World, Father of Lies, Spawn of Satan and Lord of Darkness. But I cannot speak freely now because there's this outsider here.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Sister Mary, on the other hand, had thought that the orderly's wink was more on the lines of: Sister Teresa is now voiced by Sister Mary.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER TERESA GARRULOUS
dialogues.text: Well done, that Sister Mary - switched over the babies all by herself. Now indicate to me the superfluous child and I shall remove it and let you get on with your tea with his Royal Excellency the American Culture.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And therefore her own wink had meant:  29.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: There you go, dearie; that one’s Baby B, now take him away and leave me to chat to his Excellency. He’s telling me all about the Queen and her elephants. Back to reality: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS (CONT’D) Have you picked a name for him yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Teresa hands Baby B to Mrs Dowling:

dialogues.speaker: SISTER TERESA GARRULOUS
dialogues.text: Here’s your little man back. All cleaned up and weighed. The Secret Service men edge forward nervously. One is sti filming: Mrs Dowling shows the baby to his camera.

dialogues.speaker: MRS DOWLING
dialogues.text: Look, honey. Our son.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS DOWLING
dialogues.text: He’s beautiful, hon. What a little tyke, huh? Seeing him makes me understand what’s important in life. It’s not work. I’m going to teach him to play baseball, and on Sundays we'll go fishing and, sorry hon, that’s someone on the other line. The awkwardness of the moment is increased as the Mother Superior, whom we had not seen enter the room, says, ominously:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: You must name the child.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Well, we were going to name him Thaddeus, after his pop. And his pop’s pop...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Damien’s an excellent name.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Damien Dowling? Too alliterative.  30.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Warlock, then. It’s an old English name. A good name. Harriet looks down at little Warlock.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Hello, Warlock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deirdre Young is still asleep, as is the Antichrist Baby. Sister Mary is getting into the naming.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Damien? No, I had fancied something more, well, traditional. We've always gone in for good simple names in our family.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Cain. Very modern sound, Cain, really.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS
dialogues.text: Or there's always .. . well, there's always Adam.

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: Adam? Hm. Adam... And at that moment, the baby wakes, and opens its eyes, a starts to cry... and the baby, waking, wakes Deirdre Youn

dialogues.speaker: DEIRDRE
dialogues.text: Oh. Give him here, George. Come on little one... She reaches for the crying baby and prepares to breastfee

dialogues.speaker: MR YOUNG
dialogues.text: You know, Deirdre, I think he looks like an Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley has a hands free calling system: He’s driving and says,  31.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Call Aziraphale.

dialogues.speaker: CARPHONE SYSTEM
dialogues.text: Calling Aziraphale.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE SYSTEM
dialogues.text: We are sorry. All circuits are busy. We are sorry. All circuits are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aziraphale enters, humming Schubert. Hangs up his coat. The phone on the desk rings... Aziraphale glares at it. H wants to let it ring. Then he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we're quite definitely closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley is standing in the last village phonebox in Engla to have a working payphone in it.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It’s me. We have to talk. It’s the Big One.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Crowley. “The Big One”. Really? Isn’t that a little melodramatic, even for you?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t be like that, Aziraphale. I'll explain when I see you. Usual place. Usual time.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: What’s the usual time?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Whenever I get up.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Ten thirty?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: One-ish.  32.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: When you say “The Big One..” you DO mean...?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Armageddon. Yeah. He breaks the connection. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Aziraphale looks like someone’s punched him in the stomac

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dusty red-painted truck rumbles along a dusty road that little more than a track. African music, African animals. beautiful establishing shot. Title card: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, perfect village. Children run, laughing through streets. A woman sits beside her wares in the market. And there’s a gunshot... -..no. It’s a truck, backfiring. We see it limping throug the main road, and then it makes some noises trucks shoul not make, and STOPS completely. The DRIVER gets out and lifts the trunk: thick smoke come out. An African PASSER-BY walks over.

dialogues.speaker: PASSER-BY
dialogues.text: That does not look good. The driver looks up, and we discover that she is a white woman in her 20s with the most amazing flame-red hair. Sh has an American accent. She’s called SCARLETT. She is WAR

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: Nope. It’s not. Is there a bar around here? Somewhere I can make a phone call?  33.

dialogues.speaker: PASSER-BY
dialogues.text: Over there. But you can’t just leave your truck here. Without a look back, she walks over to the bar... INT. AFRICAN BAR — DAY Scarlett opens a bottle of beer by casually slamming it a her hand against the counter, and drains it. The Bartende a bored African woman in her mid 30s.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: I got a truck. The Engine’s shot. Anyone around here I can talk to?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Only Nathan. But he’s gone back to Kaunda to his father-in-law’s farm.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: When’s he coming back?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: A week. Perhaps two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Passer-by walks around the truck. Then he peeks insid There are a lot of boxes in there. And the boxes are all stencilled with WARNINGS. High explosive. Ammunition. Gun Rocket launchers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A elderly payphone in the corner. Scarlett is talking.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know you paid for the shipment. You'll just have to wait another two weeks to start your war. There are TWO MEN sitting at a corner table, having an ea going conversation, drinking and laughing. SCARLETT (CONT’D) Don’t be like that. No, you listen to me. No. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCARLETT (CONT’D) You may have bought the equipment, but it begins when I get there... Really? REALLY? She puts down the phone, sits down at the table with the SCARLETT (CONT’D) Hey. When was the last war in these parts? The two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BAR CUSTOMER 1
dialogues.text: I don’t think we’ve ever had one.

dialogues.speaker: BAR CUSTOMER 2
dialogues.text: We don’t go in for things like that here.

dialogues.speaker: BAR CUSTOMER 1
dialogues.text: No! 1952. In the town square...

dialogues.speaker: BAR CUSTOMER 2
dialogues.text: That was not a war. And they both felt a bit silly when they woke up... Scarlett gets up and walks out of the bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out at the lazy African paradise.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: Oh, what the hell. I needed a holiday anyway. TIME SHIFT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s 24 hours later. An explosion rocks the street. A GRO OF MEN in improvised uniforms come charging down the stre A Rattling of sub-machine gun fire takes them out. They f A WOUNDED BOY behind them lobs a grenade... We follow the grenade behind improvised sandbags. The PEO BACK THERE see the grenade, and look horrified, as it blo up... We look at the Corpses on the street.  35. And then we see the Empty Truck. Five Women, one of them the Bartender, are up on the truc They have a rocket launcher.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: If the Rebels want War, we will give them war, my sisters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy African airport. Scarlett, not a hair out of place talking to a an African businessman in the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: ..+-which is why microeconomics is much more interesting than people believe. And what about you, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: You know, I think maybe it’s time for a new profession... I think I’d like to be a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: An agony auntie?

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: A war correspondent. EXT. ST JAMES’S PARK DUCKPOND - MORNING It’s morning in St James’ Park. It feels like a spy movie Our narrator is sitting on the park bench. He is eating a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: They say the ducks in St James’s park are so used to being fed by secret agents, that they’ve developed Pavlovian reactions to them. We pull back from him. There are people around the pond, pretending that they are not secret agents having clandes meetings. We can see a Russian and an American having a meeting, a British agent and a Chinese, a French and a Brazilian. In each case, they are pretending to feed the ducks.  36.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN AGENT
dialogues.text: (tossing black bread) Rudnitsky’s gone triple.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH AGENT
dialogues.text: (cucumber sandwich) If the treaty is signed, it will have global repercussions...

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH AGENT
dialogues.text: (baguette) We will match their offer...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The Russian cultural attache’s black bread is particularly sought after by the more discerning duck. Crowley and Aziraphale have been meeting here for several hundred years. Aziraphale is tossing his breadcrust to a drake. The drak pecks at it, then squawks, and DIES. Crowley has come up behind Aziraphale. They talk without looking at each other, like the other spies do.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Really, my dear. Was that necessary?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Sorry. The drake RETURNS TO LIFE, quacks and paddles off.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: We knew something was going on, of course. I’ve made enquiries. An American diplomat. Really? As if Armagedden were a cinematographic show you wished to sell in as many countries as possible.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: The Earth and all the Kingdoms thereof. Aziraphale looks at Crowley for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: We will win, of course.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You really believe that?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Obviously. Heaven finally triumphs over hell. It’s all going to be rather lovely. Crowley starts walking through the park. Aziraphale reluctantly follows him.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Out of interest, how many first class composers do your lot have in Heaven? Because Mozart’s one of ours. Beethoven. Schubert. All the Bachs...

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: They have already written their music...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: And you'll never hear it again. No more Albert Hall. No more Glyndebourne. No more proms. No Compact Disks. Just celestial harmonies.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: And that’s just the start of what you'll lose if you win. No more fascinating little restaurants where they know you. No gravlax with dill sauce. No more old bookshops. No more Regency Silver Snuffboxes.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: But after we win, life will be better for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You'll be about as happy with a harp as I'll be with a pitchfork.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: We don’t play harps.  38.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: And we don’t use pitchforks. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: But it has to happen. The Four Horsemen will ride out. The Seas will turn to blood...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: The seas are fine just as they are. It’s where your sushi comes from. They've reached Crowley’s Bentley. He’s parked it on the Mall, somewhere you can’t park. It already has a wheelcla on it, and a Traffic Warden is walking around it, writing things down in his notebook, because this is the past, wh they had notebooks.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've got about a decade. Then it’s all over. You have to help me.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I’m serious. It’s the end of the world we're talking about. Not some little temptation I've asked you to cover for me while you’re in Edinburgh for the festival. You can’t just say no.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: We can do something. I’ve got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I. Am. Not. Interested. A breath. Crowley is about to fall apart. But he pulls himself together.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Let’s have lunch. I still owe you one from... Aziraphale glares at him. Then softens...  39.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Paris. 1793.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. The Reign of Terror. Was that one of yours or one of ours? They get in to the car... The WHEELCLAMPS VANISH.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Can't recall. Quite a nice restaurant though. The Traffic Warden, who is looking triumphant, is startle when his notebook bursts into flames as the Bentley drive away.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to do that.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: That was me. I thought your people invented them.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Really? I thought they were yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan across a restaurant. It’s a fancy restaurant. Dry and liquid nitrogen. Molecular Gastronomy. It’s very fanc Aziraphale and Crowley are looking around.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Ah. Sorry about this. Under new management. Still the most expensive restaurant in London. Just now it’s molecular gastronomy. Apparently they use, er, molecules.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Not really my kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: What is your kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Well, they always do a lovely high tea at the Ritz. Crowley sighs and turns around. They leave....  40. But we remain in the restaurant. We pan across until we m the owner of the restaurant... RAVEN SABLE, who is American, dressed in black, and has t kind of beard popularised by the late Roger Delgado, or failing that, Max Maven. He looks sinister without trying is FAMINE. Title Card: II Sable looks on with approval as a WAITER brings his dinin partner, FRANNIE, his accountant and Financial Manager, a nearly empty but beautiful plate...

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Your main course, madam. Chicken froth, on a reduction of broccoli gel, with a mushroom foam. And the chef recommends this, first... He hands her a balloon...

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: What is it? It looks like a balloon.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: A balloon filled with lavender- scented air. Inhale it, then eat your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: I need another glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: Bon appetite, Frannie. So. You saw the latest royalty statement? Frannie is hungry. The molecular gastronomy is lost on he

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: 12 Million copies, Dr Sable.

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: C’mon. Eat hearty. Molecular gastronomy. Amazing, huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: It’s a lot of copies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about this place. All the money these folks pay to stay hungry. Yeah. I think it’s time to expand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: A new line of diet books?

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: Much more than that. It’s time to go corporate. A chain of fast food outlets. Factories. The whole schmear. They are interrupted by SHERRYL, a FASHION MODEL. 41. Horrendously underweight. Beautiful but dear god how can human being be that thin...?

dialogues.speaker: SHERRYL
dialogues.text: Uh. Dr Sable. I hope you don’t mind me interrupting you. But your book. It changed my life... Sherryl. Two Rs. And a Y. She puts the book down on the table. Sable’s photo cover -- “THE D-PLAN DIET.” And the subtitle “SLIM BEAUTIFUL -- TERMINALLY!” He signs, saying:

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: Why indeed? There. A quote from the book of the revelation of St John.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRYL
dialogues.text: You don’t know how much this means to me. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: That girl looks like she’s starving to death.

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: She is. She’s dying of hunger right now. So. Corporate... Frannie has an ultrathin, ultralight black laptop. stabbing at it... is on the

dialogues.speaker: YOURSELF
dialogues.text: She's  42.

dialogues.speaker: FRANNIE
dialogues.text: Already on it. We can buy into Holdings (Holdings) Incorporated for the initial Lichtenstein toehold. We use the Cayman Islands as a... Dr Sable? Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: SABLE
dialogues.text: Sorry -- It just occurred to me. I’ve never seen a room full of rich people so hungry... EXT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - DAY Crowley and Aziraphale are heading down the pavement to t Book shop.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I have several very nice little Chateuneuf De Papes in the back. I picked up a dozen cases of them in 1921, and I still have a couple of bottles left, for special occasions.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Not very big on wine in Heaven, are they? Not going to get any more nice little Chateuneuf De Papes in Heaven. Or Single malt scotch. Or little cocktails with umbrellas.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I told you, Crowley. I’m not helping you. I’m not interested. This is purely social. I’m an angel. You’re a demon. We’re hereditary enemies. Get thee behind me, foul fiend! He unlocks the door to the bookshop.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE is in his twenties. He’s beautiful, in a dirty sort way. Everything about him, overalls, face, hair, is sligh grimy... He’s mopping a deck of an oil tanker... FREEZE o his face.  43.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s called White, or Albus, or Chalky, or Snowy. He’s had lots of interesting jobs in lots of interesting places... He’s helped design the petrol engine, plastics and the ring-pull can... He can turn his hand to anything, Mr White. Title Card: III White is walking through the Tanker’s decks. He passes th Captain’s Cabin: SHOT, CAPTAIN in bed, a hand releases an empty bottle to floor of the cabin. It rolls away and back. White passes a toilet. The NOISES of someone having a miserable time being sick emerge as he passes. White walks through the galley, where the SECOND MATE is passing the time by tossing peanuts into the air and catc them in his mouth. Or failing to catch them...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The captain is drunk in his cabin. The first mate is sick with a tummy bug. The second mate is in the galley. And that doesn’t matter, because the tanker is almost entirely automated. White reaches a door marked RESTRICTED ACCESS. The door swings open as he gets there.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: There’s almost nothing left for a person can do. There’s a small Video Cam Unit in a corner, and a black a white monitor showing what’s going on inside. White ISN'T it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE walks to the Emergency Cargo Release Switch. It say “Insert KEY to Initialise EMERGENCY CARGO RELEASE”. He li a finger, thoughtfully, and twirls it in the air... As if in sympathy, lock turns, with no key in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White flicks the Cargo release switch into the RELEASE position.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE
dialogues.text: (gently. Wistfully.) Oops.

dialogues.speaker: BIRDSEYE VIEW
dialogues.text: We see the tanker below us, and, all around it a huge bla oil spill spreading out across the blue of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Afterwards, there was a huge amount of discussion as to whose fault it was. Neither the captain, the first or the second mate ever worked again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAPTAIN, FIRST MATE and SECOND MATE are led off, daze in handcuffs, by POLICE... A tiny ship, a little steamer, as different as can possib be from the gleaming huge tanker, IS PASSING IN THE BACKGROUND. We zoom in on it....

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But no-one gave any thought to Able Seaman White...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there is White, eating crisps on the deck of the stea He tosses the empty crisp packet overboard. Behind him, w pan up to see, are rusting barrels each stencilled with WEEDKILLER -- TOXIC -- EXTREMELY DANGEROUS and Death’s heads...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Nobody ever does. EXT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Establishing shot of the outside of the shop. Soho...  45. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP We move through the bookshop, listening to their conversation, until we reach the back room. There are a L of bottles of wines and spirits on the various surfaces, along with the teetering piles of books, the regency snuf box display. Crowley is Drunker than Aziraphale, but they both drunk.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: So what. Exactly. Is. Your. Point?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: My point is. My point is. The point I’m trying to make is... the dolphins. That’s my point.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Kind of fish.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Nononono, ‘S mammal. Your actual mammal. Difference is... Neither of them are very clear on the differences.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Mate out of water?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t think so. Something about their young. Not the point. The point is. Their brains. He pours himself a huge glass of wine. It takes a lot to supernatural beings drunk.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: What about their brains?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Big brains. That’s my point. Size of. Size of. Size of damn big brains. Not to mention whales. Brain city, whales, take it from me.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Kraken. Great big bugger. Supposed to rise to the surface right at the end, when the sea boils.  46.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: That's my point, whole sea bubbling, dolphins, whales, everybody turning into bouillab, bouillab, fish soup. Not their fault. Same with gorillas. Whoops, they say, sky gone all red, stars crashing to ground, what they putting in the bananas these days?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: All creatures great and small. Poor little, big...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: And you know what makes it worse. When it’s all gone. You are going to have to deal with... ETERNITY! Crowley makes a huge gesture and sends a glass and conten flying. It smashes, loudly. Aziraphale gestures, and it reforms, slightly drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Eternity? Crowley has found Aziraphale’s collection of Theatre programmes.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It won't be so bad at first. No Stephen Sondheim first nights in Eternity. But I’ve been assured He has a fondness for Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals. And He really loves the Sound of Music. Fancy spending Eternity watching that? You could literally climb every mountain over and over and over... Crowley walks around the back room...

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I don't like it any more than you, but I told you. I can't disod - not do what I'm told. 'M a'nangel. I... (pause) I can't cope with this while 'm drunk. I'm going to sober up.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Me too.  47. He closes his eyes, and jerks: We watch the all bottles around the room refill with alcohol. Crowley and Azirapha look like people who have just become un-drunk and don’t it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Young drives the car up to the Main Door. Deirdre come out, with the baby. A bunch of chattering nuns wave goodb still chattering. Over this we hear Crowley and Aziraphal talking. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Crowley is pacing, impatiently. Putting corks back into w bottles, perhaps. Aziraphale is agitated. They are both sober. And Aziraphale is coming over to the dark side.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Look! It’s not that I disagree with you. But I’m an angel. I’m not allowed to disobey.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You think I am?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: You’re a demon. You love to disobey.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: My people are only into disobedience in general terms. Not when it applies to them.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Even if I wanted to help, I couldn’t! I can't interfere with divine plans. Crowley gets an idea...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: What about diabolical ones? My lot have put the baby in play, after all. You can interfere with that!

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: But... It's still part of the overall divine plan. It’s all part of the divine plan.  48.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Then you can't be certain that thwarting me isn't part of the divine plan too. I mean, you're supposed to thwart the wiles of the Evil One at every turn, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: You see a wile, you thwart. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Broadly. Actually I encourage humans to do the actual --

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: The Antichrist is here. But birth is just the start. It's the upbringing that's important. It's the Influences. And the evil influences -- that’s all me!

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: If you put it that way, Heaven couldn't actually mind me thwarting you...

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It'd be a real feather in your wing. Aziraphale looks at him, doubtfully. Then he reaches out hand, and Crowley and Aziraphale shake hands on it.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll be godfathers, sort of. Over- seeing his upbringing. He won’t be evil. He'll be normal.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: You know, I'd never have thought of that. Godfathers. Well, I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It’s not that bad. Once you get used to it. We hear a crack of thunder...  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A storm has begun. There’s a motorcade, ready to take the Dowling baby away. Mrs Dowling comes out of the Door, wit the baby. We pull back: From the top of a nearby hill, Hastur steps from the shadows. The Mother Superior and Sister Grace Voluble runs up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: Our Mission is done, Lord Hastur. The baby is in place.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: No need for the convent any longer, then. Or for the Order.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I --

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Your order is dissolved.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: We're what?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER GRACE VOLUBLE
dialogues.text: Now hang on a moment. We did everything that was asked of us. What about our rewards?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: You irritate me. You talk too much.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER GRACE VOLUBLE
dialogues.text: We are a chattering order. We say exactly what is on our mind, and right now, what’s on my mind is that you can’t treat us like -- Hastur reaches out and puts his hand over Sister Grace’s mouth, and squeezes. She dies. Hastur looks at the Mother Superior.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell them the order is dissolved? Or do you want them all to perish in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUPERIOR
dialogues.text: (shaken) Fire?  50. Hastur gestures. Lightning strikes the roof of the Hospit The Mother Superior looks at him, and then runs back down hill. Hastur begins to laugh, and it’s absorbed by the thunder. The lights of the fire brigade are coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold on the fallen body of the late Sister Grace Volub And then we move from her to the fallen bodies in the Afr Village Square. From there to Sherryl the supermodel from the restaurant, bed, dead. From there to dead fish, floating in an oil spill... And from there back to the Weedkiller boat, and we close on the death’s head on the POISON signs. The sign of the grinning skull. Title: IV Over all this:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And there’s a Fourth. He’s everywhere, and what he does is what he is. He isn’t waiting. He’s working. Although in a manner of speaking, he’s waiting for us all.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE - DAY It's fancy, and there are secret service men outside. We a Mary Poppins style NANNY walking towards the house, wit her back to us. The doorbell is pressed. The door is opened. And the Nann wearing dark glasses, reminds us of Crowley. She’s sexy a domineering.

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: I understand you need a nanny.  51. EXT. WARLOCK’S BACK DOOR - DAY The back door is opened. A saintly friar-like GARDENER, b victorian gaffer sideburns, angelic, with a spade, who perhaps reminds us a little of Aziraphale, possibly chewi grass-blade, raises his hat and says,

dialogues.speaker: GARDENER
dialogues.text: They do say as you moight be lookin’ for a gardener. EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE GARDEN - DAY

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: A small boy in a garden. Brother Francis, the gardener, i feeding the birds... YOUNG WARLOCK, aged about 5, wanders over:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Hello Brother Francis.

dialogues.speaker: GARDENER
dialogues.text: Hullo, Young Warlock. My, you're growing fast. You must be all of...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Five. I'm five. What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GARDENER
dialogues.text: Brother Sparrow. And here’s Brother Snail... Sister Slug. Remember, Warlock, as you grow, to have love and reverence for all living things.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Nanny says Living things are only fit to be ground under my heels, Brother Francis.

dialogues.speaker: GARDENER
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to her. Listen to me. INT. WARLOCK’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Nanny has wound up the SPOOKY MUSIC BOX and the thing tha casts SCARY SHADOWS ON THE WALL. Young Warlock is in bed.  52.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Will you sing me a lullaby, Nanny?

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: Of course, dear. (sings) Go to sleep and dream of pain/ Doom and darkness, blood and brains/ Sleep so sweet, my darling boy/ You will rule, when Earth's destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Francis says that I must be kind and nice to everybody. And hug them. Even Brother slug. And not destroy the earth.

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to him. Listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top deck of a bus. Aziraphale is reading a paper. Cro sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: He’s too normal.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Not at all. It’s working. The Heavenly influences are balancing out the hellish. A no score draw.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I hope you’re right. Six years to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut between Crowley and Aziraphale entering lifts, and pushing buttons for the top floor and the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowley gets out of the lift. He saunters over to recepti Muzak in background.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Er. Crowley. Annual report.  53.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Room Five. Crowley walks down a dull corridor, past identical doors. Door Four opens, and Hastur comes out, along with a blast fire and screams from inside. He’s dusting himself off.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Hastur.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Crowley. They both go through door 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s an office. It’s shadowy, which is good, as we do not want to see the entities to whom Crowley is reporting in much detail.

dialogues.speaker: DAGON
dialogues.text: Tell uss about the boy Warlock.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: He’s a remarkable child.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Is he evil?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Fantastically evil.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Killed anyone yet?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Not yet. But there’s more to evil than just killing people. Vague noises of agreement from hellish entities: Crowley a point.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: Yeah. But it’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at the top of a skyscraper, looking out over London Aziraphale’s meeting is very similar. Nicer decor. The incredibly well-dressed, nice men and women he’s talking have faces that seem slightly burned out by light.  54.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: And I feel that, on a deep level, the child is being influenced towards the light. By me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: That sounds very commendable. Excellent work, Aziraphale. As usual.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Yes. But Aziraphale. We will be most understanding should you fail. After all, wars are to be won.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Not avoided.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Still. As he likes to say. Climb every mountain.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Ford every stream. And we finish on Aziraphale’s face, as he winces. TITLE CARD: THE PRESENT DAY. TITLE CARD: TUESDAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WARLOCK, a couple of days before his 11th birthday, is be dragged about the British Museum by his mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS DOWLING
dialogues.text: Honey. Look. It’s old. And educational.

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: It’s dumb.

dialogues.speaker: MRS DOWLING
dialogues.text: It’s not dumb, sweetie. It’s thumbscrews.

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Dumbscrews more like. Can we talk about my birthday party?  55. Mrs Dowling drags him over to the next exhibit. We pull b to see that Crowley and Aziraphale were both watching.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Thumbscrews! What normal kid doesn’t like torture?

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: But it’s good he’s not interested in torture! Isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: So. I hear that your people will be sending him a Hell Hound.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It’s the start of it all. He has to name it: Stalks By Night, or Throat-— Ripper or something. But if we’ve done our job, properly, he’ll send it away, unnamed.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: And if he does name it?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Then you and I have lost. He’1l have all his powers, and Armageddon will be just around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: At his birthday party?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: We should be there. In fact...(He’s just had an idea) I could. Entertain.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: No. Please, no.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: (wiggling his fingers) I'd just need to get back in practice. Attempts a French Drop with a coin. Drops it. Fumbles aro to pick it up, irritating tourists.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t do this. Please. I am actually begging you, and you have no idea how demeaning that is. Please. EXT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY We are in a huge tent in Warlock’s back garden. It’s a pa Birthday balloons. We have a couple of dozen eleven year olds, all very well dressed. Warlock is wearing an 11 Bad the kind you get off a birthday card. We also have some SECRET SERVICE OFFICERS. The same ones saw eleven years ago, just a little older. We have caterers, all wearing white food-serving jackets, even Crowley, who seems to be in charge of them, and is waiting by the cake. There are trifles and jellies and su Crowley looks down in embarrassment. The Kids all look bewildered -- horrified -- saddened. Because, up on a little stage... It’s AZIRAPHALE! Dressed in the style of a Victorian conjurer, top hat and tails and all, in clothes he bought hundred and fifty years ago and has not work for fifty, a has never dry cleaned, proud as punch.

dialogues.speaker: THE AMAZING MISTER FELL AND HIS REMARKABLE FEATS OF
dialogues.text: PRESTIDIGITATION is painted on a peeling old canvas in fr of him. He has a little collapsible table, a magic wand, he’s in heaven. Right now, he’s showing them his hat.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Now you sees my old top hat? Where did you get that hat, as you young uns do say? Well, you also see that there is nothing inside my perfectly normal top hat such as any of you might wear on a trip to the confectioners. But wait! What is this? Could it be our furry friend, Harry the Rabbit? A rabbit is produced from the hat. The kids are unimpress

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Dumb. It was in the table.  57.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 1
dialogues.text: You said there were going to be cartoons. I got cartoons at my birthday. An I got an Ipad an I got an Iphone an I got a smartwatch an I got a...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 2
dialogues.text: You're rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: BOY 1
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Excuse me. She’s right, you know. You are actually rubbish. Crowley is looking around for the Black Hound. He looks a the Clock -- 2 minutes to 3. Checks his watch: almost 3..

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: (pressing on) Do any of you young’uns have such a thing as a thruppeny bit about your persons? No? Well, what’s that behind your ear? Crowley is counting the seconds now. Five, four, three, two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastur and Ligur. They are standing in a huge aircraft-ha like building in Hell. A huge portcullis-like gate behind them. We can’t see the animal in there, but it would appe to be about thirty feet high and terrifying. It GROWLS. They are eyeing it nervously. A DISPOSABLE DEMON near the eyes it with stark terror.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: That’s... that’s a hell hound all right.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: It’s big.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: It’ll be what he wants it to be. You! Get in there. Open the gate!

dialogues.speaker: DISPOSABLE DEMON
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: You. Yeah. Watch out for his teeth.  58. Hastur and Ligur watch, as the demon vanishes off. Hell H growls. The Sound of a winching gate lifting... Then a SCREAM from the disposable Demon. Hastur and Ligur wince. Sound of a disposable demon being eaten.

dialogues.speaker: LIGUR
dialogues.text: It’s not like you didn’t tell him to look out for the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: HASTUR
dialogues.text: Point. Now. He’s free to find his master... They look up, scared, as the shadow of something huge goe past them... INT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY Crowley’s watch says 3 pm. Crowley looks around. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BOY 1
dialogues.text: This sucks.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: And for my next remarkable illusion, I will need a pocket handkerchief. A perfectly normal one. Does anyone have a pocket handkerchief? Blank kids. Some of them have pulled out their phones and playing video games.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do. I really will need a handkerchief. I... He blinks and performs a miracle. Ping! Turns to a Securi Guard...
