dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, my fine young jack-sauce. If you look in your pocket, I have no doubt you will find a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: M’afraid not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: No. You do. Just look. Please look.  59. The guard reaches into his inside pocket, and looks puzzl Then pulls out AN ENORMOUS LACE-EDGED HANKIE which goes n into his pocket, but into his shoulder holster... and whi as he pulls it out, snags his gun. The gun ARCS slowly and gracefully and in slow motion thr the air. It splashes down in a bowl of trifle near Warlock. The kids applaud. This is more like it!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 2
dialogues.text: Not bad. Warlock grabs the gun. Covers the room.

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Hands up lowlife scumbuckets! I got a gun. A beat. The Guards look around, panicky, and aren’t sure to do...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 1
dialogues.text: S'not fair. Why have you got a gun and we don’t?

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: I’m not stopping you. Girl 1 is next to a Security Guard, and grabs at his gun. The Guard doesn’t quite know how to deal with this. Boy 1 throws a lump of cake at Warlock, who whirls around and reflexively, squeezes the trigger... FREEZE IMAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the Narrator’s World, and the scene is on a big Screen. The Narrator is standing beside it.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The .357 Magnum Hollow point cartridge, coming out of a secret service Sig Sauer P229 at 1,430 feet per second, is capable of blowing anyone away, leaving only a red mist in the air, a messy corpse and a certain amount of paperwork. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would have taken a miracle to avoid a massacre. INT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY Close up on Aziraphale’s face. He does a Miracle Blink, a A STREAM OF WATER comes from the nozzle of Warlock’s gun. Which is now a water pistol. Aziraphale looks rather proud of himself. And then a huge lump of birthday trifle HITS HIM IN THE F Guards are (puzzled) firing water pistol guns. Kids are (enthusiastically) firing water pistol guns. Perfectly timed lumps of jelly and trifle and cake are be thrown around. IT’S A FOOD FIGHT!

dialogues.speaker: WARLOCK
dialogues.text: Best Eleventh Birthday ever! And through the chaos and the flying food, Crowley walks perfectly unharmed, untouched, barely paying attention to chaos, checking his watch, removing his white caterer’s jacket, and dropping it onto the ground... EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE - DAY The street outside. Crowley is standing, looking worried. Aziraphale joins him. He’s reaching into his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: It was all a bit of a mess, I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You gave them all a party to remember. Last one they’1ll ever have, mind... Aziraphale has removed the dove from his sleeve. He’s prodding it, but it’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: It’s late.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Comes of putting it up your sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Hell Hound. It’s late. Crowley irritably taps the dead dove, which flutters and flies off. He reaches into the Bentley and turns on the radio. It’s JUST A MINUTE...

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS PARSONS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And you have Just a Minute to tell us all about Fish Fingers starting Hello Crowley. Is sssomething wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Um. Hi. Who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS PARSONS
dialogues.text: Dagon. Lord of the Files. Master of Torments.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just checking in about the Hell Hound...

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS PARSONS
dialogues.text: We freed him. He walks to find his master. Is something wrong, Crowley?

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Wrong? No.... Nothing’s wrong. What could be wrong? I can see it now. What a lovely big helly hell hound. Hey, great talking to you. He turns off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: No dog.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: No dog.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Wrong boy.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Wrong boy. There’s a gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: (not swearing) Oh sugar! I must have missed one. 61.  62.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Armageddon is days away. And we've lost the Antichrist. Get in. Aziraphale just stands there, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: How can you lose the Antichrist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both shocked.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: You said it was him.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It was him. I should know. I delivered the baby. Not delivered- delivered it. You know. Handed it over.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Someone else must be interfering, then.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Who? There isn’t anyone else. There’s good, that’s your lot. There’s evil. That’s mine. One side or the other. And between us, we've lost the antichrist.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. Even Heaven was certain that the Hell Hound would be showing up today.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: It was sent. And the boy was meant to have named it. You have to name the beast: it gives it its purpose and its function. It’1l be stalks by night, or throat-ripper or something.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Perhaps he won’t name it.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: He’1ll name it. I’m screwed. Do you know what they can do to you down there?  63.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: The same sort of thing they can do to you up there.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you lot get ineffable mercy.

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: Remember Sodom and Gomorrah? That was my team.

dialogues.speaker: CROWLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, the good times. There was a little bar you could get a fermented date palm cocktail...

dialogues.speaker: AZIRAPHALE
dialogues.text: I mean, after. (pause) So if that appalling child wasn’t the antichrist, where in blessed blazes is he? And where’s the Hell Hound? And what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still a beautiful little village in England. We are movin through it. The clock on the village steeple is striking Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! There’s a sort of an abandoned quarry down there, through the bushes. It’s a perfect place for kids to play area of natural beauty that adults have forgotten. And there’s a lane above it. Birds are singing. A lazy bumble bee buzzes in the flower the side of the lane. Down in the quarry we can see CHILDREN, four of them, all about eleven, playing. They are a gang of Four, called The Them, and we will mee them next episode. They look harmless and sweet and VULNERABLE...  64. And one of them is swinging down a rope, in a repeat of t Zip-Line incident, only rather more successful: Golden- haired, glorious, the ultimate 11 year old. It MUST be AD And now we hear something, as the last of the bell chimes fades away. Something metallic and disturbing, rumbling a nightmarish. A ripping, rumbling noise, and now, LOOK! There’s a beat in front of us, on the lane, appears, from Hell -- THE HELL HOUND. If we can, this should be a REAL big black dog, possibly enhanced. It’s huge: a terrifying monster of a dog. The H of the Baskervilles would take one look at this brute and flee, whimpering. The Dog’s eyes are glowing red. It drip saliva. It looks at the kids below, hungrily and evilly... And it opens its mouth and GROWLS terrifyingly, showing h and awful teeth as we - FADE TO BLACK. OVER END CREDITS, BUDDY HOLLY’S “EVERY DAY”, THIS TIME DO BY A BOYS’ CHOIR, IN THE STYLE OF CARMINA BURANA.
